text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
(1) CCDM 32.1.9, Closing a Regulation Project, is being updated to reﬂect current practices.
CCDM 32.1.9.2 is updated to reﬂect new closing classiﬁcation codes.
This section supersedes CCDM 32.1.9, dated August 11, 2004.
Chief Counsel
Table of Contents
Criteria for Closing a Regulation Project Final Regulation Published NPRM Published But Will Not be No Regulation Published Closed Regulation File Assembly
Regulation Project

) A regulation project can be closed only after a. The IRS withdraws an NPRM or publishes it as a ﬁnal regulation, a b. In the case of a temporary regulations with a cross-referencing NPRM, the IRS removes the temporary regulations and withdraws the NPRM published it as a ﬁnal regulation, or c. The IRS decides not to publish a regulation. (
) After a ﬁnal regulation is published, the drafting attorney should use Form

, Treasury Decision File Closing Information Sheet and Assembly Checklist, to assemble and organize the folder(s) of the legal ﬁle. The attorney should use a two-hole punch to put holes in the top of each paper document and put the papers and documents in the folders using ﬁle fasteners. The drafting attorney should send the legal ﬁle to the tions, Records, and User Fee Unit (CC:PA:LPD:DRU) in room
as soon possible after publication of the ﬁnal regulation. (
) After a ﬁnal regulation is published, the drafting attorney should ensure that ﬁnal regulation is closed on CASE-MIS using status code

(closed – cation) and classiﬁcation code W (Regulations, revenue ruling, revenue procedure, IRB notice & announcement (non-ministerial)). The Publications and Regulations Branch enters the Federal Register ﬁling and publication mation on CASE-MIS. (

) If the IRS will not publish an NPRM as a ﬁnal regulation, the NPRM should withdrawn before closing the regulation project. To withdraw a regulation, a But withdrawal of notice of proposed rulemaking must be signed by the sioner, approved by Treasury, and published in the Federal Register. Once NPRM is withdrawn, the drafting attorney should assemble the legal ﬁle and forward it to the Communications, Records, and User Fee Unit (CC:PA:LPD:DRU). The drafting attorney should ensure that the regulation project is closed on CASE-MIS using status code
(closed – withdrawn). (

) Occasionally, the IRS decides not to publish an NPRM as a ﬁnal regulation and does not issue a withdrawal of notice of proposed rulemaking. In that situation, the regulation project remains open in CASE-MIS with status code
(NPRM published) and classiﬁcation code W (Regulations, revenue revenue procedure, IRB notice & announcement (non-ministerial)). See Exhibit
, Sample Withdrawal of Notice of Proposed Rulemaking. (

) If the IRS will not publish a regulation, prepare a closing memorandum for signature of the Associate Chief Counsel stating the reason the project is Published closed. Include the closing memorandum in the legal ﬁle. Send the legal ﬁle the Communications, Records, and User Fee Unit (CC:PA:LPD:DRU) for storage. Files closed by nonpublication will be retained in accordance with records control schedule set forth in Document
, Records and tion Management Records Control Schedules. Close the regulation project CASE-MIS using status code
(closed – non-publication) and code W (Regulations, revenue ruling, revenue procedure, IRB notice & an- nouncement (non-ministerial)). (
) An open regulation project may be closed by nonpublication for any of the following reasons: (
) Chief Counsel Directives Manual
(08-01-2018) NPRM Published But Will Not be Finalized

Chief Counsel Regulation a. The matter involves an issue speciﬁcally addressed by another open regulation project, b. The issue is answered by statute, treaty, or regulations, or will be answered by pending legislation; answered by publications or court opinions previously published in the IRB; involves a determination of rather than an interpretation of law; or is of insufficient importance or interest to warrant publication. c. The matter is recommended for nonpublication by an Associate Chief Counsel, a Division Counsel, the Chief Counsel, the Commissioner, a Treasury official. (

) If an open regulation project is identiﬁed as an appropriate subject for lication, a nonpublication memorandum is prepared by the drafting attorney the signature of the Associate Chief Counsel. After the memorandum is approved by the Associate Chief Counsel, the original is included in the ﬁle. (

) The body of the nonpublication memorandum must contain the following in separate paragraphs: • Introduction: A statement that the project is under consideration; a scription of the regulation project; the date of issuance of any document; and • Background or Reason for Nonpublication: A discussion of the ments or events that led to a conclusion that the regulation should closed by nonpublication. The memorandum should contain information for the Associate Chief Counsel to determine whether regulation should be closed without reviewing the ﬁle. • Action: A direct statement that the project is being closed and no consideration will be given to its publication. (
) See Exhibit
, Sample Closing Memorandum by Nonpublication. (
) Follow the procedures on Form
, Treasury Decision File Closing tion Sheet and Assembly Checklist, for assembling the contents of the File ﬁle. See Exhibit
, Form
, TD File Closing: Information Sheet Assembly Checklist. (
) See CCDM
) for a list of documents that should be included in the legal ﬁle.
32.1 Chief Counsel Regulation Handbook

a. The matter involves an issue speciﬁcally addressed by another open regulation project, b. The issue is answered by statute, treaty, or regulations, or will be answered by pending legislation; answered by publications or court opinions previously published in the IRB; involves a determination of rather than an interpretation of law; or is of insufficient importance or interest to warrant publication. c. The matter is recommended for nonpublication by an Associate Chief Counsel, a Division Counsel, the Chief Counsel, the Commissioner, or a Treasury official.
Introduction: A statement that the project is under consideration; a de
scription of the regulation project; the date of issuance of any relevant document; and Background or Reason for Nonpublication: A discussion of the develop

ments or events that led to a conclusion that the regulation should be closed by nonpublication. The memorandum should contain sufficient information for the Associate Chief Counsel to determine whether the regulation should be closed without reviewing the ﬁle. Action: A direct statement that the project is being closed and no further consideration will be given to its publication.
Follow the procedures on Form
, Treasury Decision File Closing Informa- tion Sheet and Assembly Checklist, for assembling the contents of the legal ﬁle. See Exhibit
, Form
, TD File Closing: Information Sheet And Assembly Checklist.

Exhibit 32.1.9-2 (08-11-2004) Sample Closing Memorandum by Nonpublication

We have under consideration the publication of a [regulation or other form of publishedguidance] based on a [describe source of regulation or other form of published guidanceproject]. The proposed [regulation or other form of published guidance] would address[insert description of project].

[Insert discussion of the reason(s) for nonpublication. This memorandum shouldcontain sufficient information to enable the Associate Chief Counsel to determinewhether the project should be closed without the Associate Chief Counsel needingreview the legal file.]
Accordingly, this project is being closed and no further consideration will be given to itspublication.
The file in this case should be classified [add file classification] and returned to [insertname of initiator].
